Review Recent advances of ammoxidation in clean energy exploitation and sewage purification: A mini review Yingzhen Zhang a Jianying Huang a b * Yuekun Lai a b * a National Engineering Research Center of Chemical Fertilizer Catalyst (NERC-CFC), College of Chemical Engineering, Fuzhou University, Fuzhou 350116, Fujian, China National Engineering Research Center of Chemical Fertilizer Catalyst (NERC-CFC) College of Chemical Engineering Fuzhou University Fuzhou Fujian 350116 China National Engineering Research Center of Chemical Fertilizer Catalyst (NERC-CFC), College of Chemical Engineering, Fuzhou University, Fuzhou 350116, Fujian, China b Qingyuan Innovation Laboratory, Quanzhou 362801, Fujian, China Qingyuan Innovation Laboratory Quanzhou Fujian 362801 China Qingyuan Innovation Laboratory, Quanzhou 362801, Fujian, China * Corresponding author. In recent decades, the advancement of clean energy technologies and sewage purification has emerged as a focal point of research. This review focuses on the ammonia oxidation reaction (AOR) and summarizes its multifaceted applications, including its use in direct ammonia fuel cells (DAFCs), its coupling with the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), and its significance in ammonia-containing sewage purification. We discuss how the combination of in-situ characterization techniques and theoretical models has emerged as a powerful tool for exploring the AOR mechanism. The interplay of operational parameters such as temperature and pH, along with catalyst design, is emphasized in the context of DAFCs, highlighting the need for precise optimization to enhance efficiency. The importance of selectivity in the nitrogen gas product in ammonia-containing wastewater is also discussed. Furthermore, the review addresses the challenges and opportunities in AOR research, including strategies to enhance catalytic activity, identify active centers, maximize the utilization of catalyst atoms, and improve selectivity while ensuring catalyst durability. Ultimately, this review serves as a comprehensive guide for researchers and practitioners interested in harnessing the potential of AOR to bridge the gap between clean energy generation and sustainable wastewater treatment, offering insights into a greener and more environmentally responsible future. Graphical Abstract This review summarizes the recent advancements in AOR research, highlights the challenges and opportunities inherent in AOR processes, and offers valuable insights for research in the fields of clean energy and the environment. Keywords Ammonia oxidation reaction Direct ammonia fuel cells Hydrogen Sewage purification Clean energy Electrocatalysis 1 Introduction During the past several decades, the tremendous advancements in science and technology have led to a dramatic increase in energy demand. Nevertheless, the limitations arising from resource scarcity, non-renewability, and the environmentally adverse byproducts stemming from the combustion of conventional fossil fuels such as coal and petroleum [1–3] have propelled the exploration and adoption of novel clean energy sources in the realm of energy conversion. Concerns about climate change and the need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions have made the exploitation of carbon-free energy carriers important. Fig. 1(a) shows that the energy density of ammonia (NH3) is higher (4.3 kWh kg−1 [4]) than that of other carbon-free fuels (e.g., liquid hydrogen) and Li batteries [5]. In particular, ammonia has the advantages of high hydrogen content, harmless combustion products (N2 and H2O), large-scale production, and superior compressibility, as well as easy storage and transportation [6–8]. As a result, it is considered a promising candidate fuel, serving as the foundation for the development of direct ammonia fuel cells (DAFCs). Fig. 1(b) displays the operating principle of a DAFCs, where the cathodic oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is coupled with the anodic ammonia oxidation reaction (AOR) [9]. Although hydrogen (H2) is also a carbon-free and environmentally friendly source of energy [10], the technology of hydrogen production, such as coal gasification and methane steam reforming [11,12] produces a mass of adverse substances (e.g., CO2), placing a serious burden on the environment. Hydrogen production from water electrolysis powered by renewable sources (e.g., wind and tidal energy) [13–15] is a promising approach to mitigate these detriments, but its efficiency is limited by the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) process, where electrons react quickly, and protons react slowly [16]. It is worth noting that AOR has the potential to replace the OER while coupling with the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) in a water-splitting system [17], thereby achieving low-energy and high-efficiency hydrogen production, as depicted in Fig. 1(c). This potential stems from the fact that the theoretical potential of the AOR (0.06 V vs. RHE) is lower than that of the OER (1.23 V vs. RHE) [18]. Nonetheless, it is important to highlight that ammonia cannot be completely converted into harmless nitrogen due to factors such as low catalytic efficiency, poor reaction selectivity, and harsh operating environment. Fig. 1(d) illustrates that the nitrogenous product may include N2, NO, N2O, NO2 −, or NO3 −, depending on ammonia concentration, pH, and applied potential [17]. Specifically, varying ammonia concentrations can lead to competition between different reaction pathways, resulting in the generation of diverse nitrogen-containing species. Similarly, the pH of the reaction environment can influence the protonation states of active sites, which, in turn, alter adsorption properties and catalytic behavior. Furthermore, the applied potential can determine the energy profile of the reaction, directing it toward specific product formations. In addition to the increasing demand for energy and the vigorous development of industrial technology, which has greatly benefited the progress of human society, it has also given rise to numerous negative environmental issues that cannot be ignored. Industrial and agricultural production activities, such as coking, ammonia synthesis, and aquaculture [20–23], generate a substantial amount of ammonia-containing wastewater, which poses significant challenges to the aquatic environment. The presence of ammonia-nitrogen in sewage can decrease the concentration of dissolved oxygen in water, resulting in water discoloration, foul odors, and deteriorated water quality. This, in turn, threatens the survival of aquatic organisms and plants [24,25]. Therefore, the World Health Organization (WHO) has set the maximum allowable concentration of ammonia at approximately 1.5 mg L−1, with a taste threshold of 35 mg L−1 [26]. Traditional technologies for ammonia-nitrogen removal encompass the following methods: (1) Air oxidation method [27]: This method involves exposing ammonia-containing water to air, allowing oxygen to oxidize ammonia into nitrite or nitrogen. While it is a straightforward approach, it exhibits lower treatment efficiency and necessitates longer oxidation times. (2) Chemical precipitation method [28]: This method requires the addition of metal salts (e.g., ferric chloride or aluminum sulfate) to form precipitates by converting ammonia into insoluble iron hydroxide or aluminum hydroxide. While effective for high-concentration ammonia nitrogen, this method generates a significant amount of sludge. (3) Ion exchange method [29]: In this approach, ion exchange resins are utilized to adsorb the ammonium ions in the effluent and remove them. This technology is well-suited for treating low-concentration ammonia but mandates regular resin regeneration. (4) Membrane separation method [30]: This method involves the utilization of reverse osmosis or nanofiltration membranes to separate ammonia from wastewater. This method offers high efficiency and excellent selectivity, albeit it comes with elevated operation and maintenance expenses. Traditional approaches for ammonia-nitrogen removal, as mentioned above, suffer from limitations regarding treatment efficiency, energy consumption, waste management, and complexity. Consequently, there is a pressing need for further research and development to uncover more efficient, cost-effective, and environmentally friendly techniques for ammonia removal. Fortunately, the electrochemical ammonia oxidation strategy emerges as a promising means of removing ammonia from wastewater, offering several advantages such as simplicity, affordability, efficiency, and environmental friendliness [28,29]. To enhance the application of AOR in the fields of energy and environmental science, it becomes crucial to acquire a comprehensive understanding of the research development pertaining to AOR mechanisms. Recent pioneering studies in this domain have been consolidated into a developmental history chart (Fig. 2 ). Presently, there remains a significant ongoing discourse concerning the intermediate products of AOR and the mechanisms governing selective N2 generation. This, in turn, underscores the necessity for further research in this area. While previous reviews have offered comprehensive summaries of ammonia oxidation technologies [30–32], a discernible gap still persists in our comprehension of the precise reaction mechanisms and intermediates involved in AOR. Consequently, it becomes imperative to provide a timely overview of the real-time detection methods for intermediate species and the latest developments in this field. Such insights will be instrumental in guiding the rational design of catalysts for AOR within the energy and environmental sectors. As a result, this review aims to enrich our understanding of the AOR mechanisms, in-situ monitoring techniques, the most recent research advancements, challenges, and anticipated future trends within this field. 2 Mechanism of AOR In order to advance the application of AOR in fields such as fuel cells, water purification, and hydrogen production, it is essential to gain a comprehensive understanding of the reaction mechanism. Previous researchers have conducted extensive investigations into the AOR mechanism, leading to the identification of two established mechanisms. As depicted in Fig. 3 , one was initially proposed by Oswin and Salomonm in 1963 [35], referred to as the O-S mechanism or N-N mechanism. This mechanism suggests that the ammonia undergoes complete dehydrogenation to produce surface-bound nitrogen atoms (*N), which subsequently couple to form N2. The other mechanism, put forth by Gerischer and Mauerer in 1970 [36] and known as the G-M mechanism, posits that the ammonia undergoes partial dehydrogenation and dimerization to create *N2H y (where y = 2, 3, and 4), followed by a gradual dehydrogenation of *N2H y to form N2. However, the actual mechanism under specific conditions is intricate and variable; *N (in the O-S mechanism) and the *N2H y (in the G-M mechanism) can potentially react with OH− in an alkaline solution to generate unwanted nitrogen oxides, such as NO, NO2 −, and NO3 −. These complex intermediates and byproducts present significant challenges when attempting to conduct a detailed study of the practical mechanism of AOR. Considering the energy efficiency and activity of AOR in fuel cells, Manos and colleagues employed the first-principles methods to investigate the reaction mechanism of AOR on model close-packed surfaces of various metals, including Au, Ag, Cu, Pd, Pt, Ni, Ir, Co, Rh, Ru, Os, and Re, using the N-N mechanism and G-M mechanism [36]. Their findings suggest that Au, Ru, Re, Os, and Rh are susceptible to poisoning by *N species (Fig. 4(a) ), primarily because their rate-determining step involves the formation of *N species, which are known to be catalyst-inactivating species. Additionally, the AOR onset potential on Ag is too high (0.92 V), rendering it unsuitable for practical applications. To further select the most suitable AOR catalyst, they calculated the activity and binding energy (Fig. 4(b)). Their calculations revealed the following: (1) Co, despite having the lowest onset potential, exhibits a prohibitively high N–N bond formation energy, which limits its catalytic activity; (2) Cu possesses the lowest N–N bond formation energy; (3) Pt emerges as the most active catalyst, followed by Ir, Cu, and Pd. Furthermore, they calculated the free energy and transition state (TS) of the AOR process on Pt(111) and Cu(111) surfaces. As shown in Figs. 4(c) and 4(d), the AOR process tends to proceed via the G-M mechanism on Pt(111) and Cu(111) surfaces. Therefore, the strategic combination of Pt and Cu may hold the potential to develop exceptionally effective catalysts. Pt is widely recognized as the most effective catalyst for AOR. However, its potential for commercialization is hindered by its scarcity and high cost. To address this issue, Estejab's research group [37] employed density functional theory (DFT) to calculate the adsorption energy of NH3 and its intermediates on Pt3–x Ir x (where x = 0, 1, 2, and 3). They analyzed the reaction pathway (Fig. 5(a) ) and demonstrated that the intermediates exhibit greater stability when following the O-S mechanism (indicated by the red dotted frame) rather than the G-M mechanism (indicated by the pink dotted frame). This increased stability was attributed to the electronic effects of Ir in combination with Pt. Furthermore, Wu et al. [38], through both experimental and DFT approaches, corroborated that the PtIrNi alloy nanoparticles, when uniformly dispersed on binary composite supports composed of porous silica (SiO2) and carboxy-functionalized carbon nanotubes (PtIrNi/SiO2-CNT-COOH, Fig. 5(b)), exhibit a preference for the AOR through O-S mechanism. Figs. 5(c)–(e) illustrate that the d-band center of the alloy is in closer proximity to the Fermi-level, and each step of dehydrogenation represents an exothermic reaction on the (100) facet of Pt3Ir and Pt3IrNi, in contrast to Pt (100). In the context of incomplete AOR, considering the NO and N2O byproducts, Shan et al. [39] investigated the selectivity of AOR on the low-index facets of representative metals (Ag, Au, Cu, Ir, Pd, Pt, Rh, and Ru). This study highlighted that achieving appropriate N-binding energy within the range of 5.0 to 4.0 eV and enhancing the O-binding capability can lead to remarkable catalytic activity and improved N2 selectivity (Figs. 5(f) and (g)), respectively. However, it is worth noting that the aforementioned research primarily centers around noble metal-based catalysts for the AOR mechanism. Given the promising outlook for long-term industrial applications, the development of catalysts that exhibit both high AOR activity and durability has become imperative. Guo et al. [40] investigated the reactivity and stability of the AOR process undergoing a G-M mechanism on non-precious metal clusters (Fe6M, where M represents Fe, Mo, Ni, and Co) by analyzing the adsorption energy and reaction barriers. Fig. 6(a) illustrates that the introduction of foreign atoms into Fe clusters enhances their stability, except for the Co atom. The initial step in the AOR process involves the adsorption of ammonia, in which the electron cloud density and adsorption energy could effectively determine the adsorption capacity. Notably, ammonia possesses a lone pair of electrons, and its electron cloud density undergoes changes upon adsorption to the catalyst (Fig. 6(b)). Specifically, the addition of Mo to the top of Fe clusters, denoted as Fe6Mo(t), exhibits the highest ammonia adsorption capacity (Fig. 6(c)). Furthermore, different active centers (*Mo(t), *Fe(t), and *Fe(l), where * represents the active site) within Fe6Mo(t) display distinct reaction pathways (Figs. 6(d) and (e)). Among them, *Fe(t) as the active center exhibits the lowest reaction energy barrier at 2.60 eV. This study provides valuable insights for exploring the mechanisms of non-noble metal catalysts involved in AOR. In-situ characterization techniques are highly effective and essential for uncovering the mechanisms of catalytic reactions. With the continuous advancement of scientific technology and the pursuit of a deeper understanding of catalytic reactions, various in-situ techniques have found widespread use in fields such as electrochemical CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR), urea oxidation reaction, and nitrate electrocatalytic reduction reaction (NO3RR) for ammonia synthesis, among others. These techniques, including in-situ differential electrochemical mass spectrometry, in-situ Raman spectroscopy, in-situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), in-situ ultraviolet-visible (UV-Vis) spectroscopy, quasi-in-situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, and in-situ scanning/transmission electron microscopy, are employed to detect reaction intermediates or catalyst restructuring processes [41–45]. Nevertheless, existing literature highlights a lack of examples demonstrating the application of in-situ techniques in the field of electrochemical AOR. Koichi and colleagues [46] utilized in-situ FTIR to monitor AOR intermediates on the surface of Pt catalysts. They observed that at low voltage (0.1 V vs. RHE), ammonia was spontaneously adsorbed to the Pt surface. As the voltage increased to 0.2 V vs. RHE, an absorption peak at 1269 cm−1 appeared in the in-situ FTIR spectrum (Fig. 7(a) ), indicating the formation of N2H4 dimer. Further increasing the voltage to 0.5 V vs. RHE revealed a characteristic peak corresponding to N=O stretch vibration in the range of 1497–1508 cm−1, indicating the presence of NO species. Additionally, their study demonstrated that the adsorption of NO on the catalyst surface led to a reduction in current density (Fig. 7(b)). They suggested that NO was a toxic species that could deactivate the catalyst. This research uncovered two potential pathways for the AOR process: (1) the *NH2 intermediates dimerized to form N2H4, which was subsequently dehydrogenated to form N2, in accordance with the G-M mechanism, and (2) The *N intermediates bound to oxygen in the solvent to produce NO, which occupied active sites and resulted in catalyst deactivation. It was also noted that the selectivity for N2 could be enhanced by optimizing the reaction potential (Fig. 7(c)). Furthermore, using in-situ UV-Vis spectroscopy, He Hong's research team reported that the surface plasmon resonance effect of silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) and silver nanoclusters (Ag n 0) gradually weakens or even disappears with increasing reaction temperature, as illustrated in Fig. 8(a) , during the thermal AOR process [47]. This demonstrates that change in reaction temperature has a direct impact on catalyst activity. Additionally, they employed in-situ FTIR spectroscopy to trace the path of AOR during the thermal catalysis process. The stretching vibrations of NH3 adsorbed on the Lewis acid site were observed at 1212, 1265, and 1615 cm−1 (Fig. 8(b)), while the deformation vibrations of NH3 on the Br⊘nsted acid site was observed at 1450 and 1690 cm−1. Moreover, they discovered that the N=N stretching vibration, possibly related to NH=NH, N2, and N2O species, appeared at 2170 cm−1 as the temperature rose to 150 °C (Fig. 8(c)). Their study unveiled that the AOR products are N2 and N2O in the reaction temperature range of 150 to 225 °C, N2 in the range of 225 to 350 °C, and a mixture of N2 and NO in the range of 350 to 450 °C. This revelation suggests that the selectivity of AOR products can be optimized by adjusting the reaction temperature, as depicted in Fig. 8(d). Clearly, in-situ techniques prove to be effective tools for unraveling the catalytic mechanisms. They hold significant potential for application in the field of electrochemical ammonia oxidation reactions, further enhancing our understanding of the mechanism behind ammonia's role in the electrooxidation process. 3 Applications of the ammoxidation reaction 3.1 Direct ammonia fuel cell The direct ammonia fuel cell (DAFC) is an electrochemical device that utilizes ammonia as its fuel source. Ammonia's oxidation potential closely resembles that of hydrogen, allowing a DAFC fueled by ammonia to yield a voltage similar to that of a hydrogen fuel cell. Ammonia fuel cells offer several advantages over hydrogen fuel cells. Firstly, ammonia is a renewable resource that can be relatively easily stored and transported. Secondly, ammonia gas for these fuel cells can be obtained through the industrial ammonia synthesis process, establishing a convenient supply chain. Moreover, ammonia fuel cells produce only water as an oxidation product, resulting in no greenhouse gas emissions or pollutants like carbon dioxide, thus minimizing their environmental impact. However, DAFC faces three significant challenges: (1) Ammonia's high solubility in water presents a challenge, with the competing reaction of OER; (2) the electrolyte's pH value significantly impacts the energy conversion efficiency of the DAFC; and (3) the working temperature plays a crucial role in determining the performance of DAFC. To improve the energy conversion efficiency of DAFCs, John F. Berry et al. [6] reported a stable metal-metal bonded complex called Ru2(chp)4OTf (chp: 6-chloro-2-hydroxypyridinate, OTf: trifluoromethanesulfonate). They utilized theoretical calculations to analyze the reaction mechanism and found that this double ruthenium complex catalyst can effectively electrocatalyze the conversion of ammonia to N2 at a low potential of –255 mV vs. Fc+/0 under room temperature conditions. Importantly, this process avoids the formation of high oxidation state intermediates like NO2 − and NO3 −. This beneficial characteristic is attributed to the ability of the complex to promote multi-electron reactions through d-orbital interactions. The electrode resistance, which is one of the key factors influencing the energy conversion efficiency of DAFC [48], decreases as the concentration of OH− increases. Yan et al. [22] observed that higher concentrations of hydroxide ions lead to a lower onset potential (E onset) and an increase in the maximum peak current density (j max) in a 3.0 mol L−1 KOH electrolyte (Fig. 9(a) ). When the current remained below 200 mA cm−2, the activity of the DAFC was increased with the rising OH− concentration. Notably, this study revealed a decrease in power density in a 5.0 mol L−1 KOH solution, at a high current density of 200 mA cm−2, possibly due to limitations in NH3 transport at the anode or H2O transport at the cathode. In the case of a 3.0 mol L−1 KOH solution, the fuel cell achieved its maximum power density of 135 mW cm−2 at 500 mA cm−2 (Fig. 9(b)) while operating at a temperature of 80 °C. In addition, Wu et al. [49] prepared an AOR catalyst consisting of ternary PtIrZn nanoparticles, evenly dispersed on a support comprising cerium oxide (CeO2) and zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 (referred to as PtIrZn/CeO2-ZIF-8). They also observed that the E onset decreased, and the current density increased with higher OH− concentration (Fig. 9(c)). As the OH− concentration was increased from 1.0 to 5.0 mol L−1, the E onset decreased from 0.345 to 0.314 V, and the peak current density increased from 31.8 to 65.1 A g−1. These results can be attributed to the reduction in solution resistance (Fig. 9(d)). At the same potential (0.5 V), the current density increased from 9.4 to 17.6 A g−1 as the KOH concentration changed from 0.05 to 1.0 mol L−1 (Fig. 9(e)). Furthermore, the peak power density reached 314 mW cm−2 at 95 °C, in a 1.25 mol L−1 KOH electrolyte (Fig. 9(f)). DFT calculations also revealed that the heteroatomic Zn in PtIr alloys facilitates the dehydrogenation of *NH2 to *NH. This is due to the weak d-d coupling between Zn atoms and PtIr groups, which shifts the d-band center upward and promotes N–H bond cleavage. In a study by Liu's group [50], they fabricated core-shell nanoparticles of NiCu@NiCuOOH on nickel foam surfaces through electrodeposition. In ammonia-containing electrolytes, the catalyst demonstrated high ammonia catalytic activity with a current density of 90 mA cm−2 (Fig. 9(g)). This can be attributed to the unique three-dimensional core-shell structure, enabling the efficient transfer of electrons from NiCu to Ni-Cu-OOH, abundant active sites, and enhanced ion diffusion, thus boosting the AOR activity. In Fig. 9(h), the NiCu@NiCuOOH exhibits a smaller apparent activation energy (E a, 33.64 kJ mol−1) compared to NiCu (39.13 kJ mol−1), which suggests that the former is more conducive to breaking the N–H bond. Additionally, both the power density (17.5 mW cm−2) and the current density (140 mA cm−2) reached their peaks under the high OH− concentration conditions, as shown in Fig. 9(i). Given that pH significantly influences the reaction kinetics and active site behavior in AOR, it is essential to conduct comprehensive investigations to identify the pH conditions that yield optimal performance. Researchers can explore pH-dependent electrochemical behavior, active site protonation, and the effects of pH on catalyst stability. These insights could potentially lead to the design of catalysts with improved pH tolerance and efficiency. The operating temperature plays a crucial role in the performance of DAFC. An earlier study conducted by An's research group [51] revealed that raising the working temperature from 80 to 95 °C led to gradual increases in both the cell voltage (from 0.47 to 0.66 V) and the peak power density (from 1.70 to 19.68 mW cm−2) (Fig. 10(a) ). Tao's research group [52] also observed that as the temperature increased from 20 to 40 °C, the cell voltage increased from 0.3 to 0.6 V (Fig. 10(b)); however, when the temperature reached 60 °C, the cell voltage remained relatively constant. As the operating temperature was further increased, the current density exhibited a significant rise, reaching a maximum of 379 mA cm−2, along with a power density of 34 mW cm−2 at 100 °C, which was comparable to that of commercial Pt/C (Fig. 10(c)). In a separate study, Wang et al. [53] synthesized a PtIr/C catalyst and employed the CV method to verify that an increase in temperature promotes the AOR and reduces the negative impact of activation loss on cell performance (Fig. 10(d)). 3.2 AOR-Boosted water splitting for H2 production Constrained by the non-renewable and environmentally harmful nature of traditional energy sources such as natural gas and coal [54], there is an urgent need to develop sustainable and eco-friendly energy alternatives [55]. Fortunately, clean energy sources that do not release minimal pollutants or greenhouse gases into the environment have gained significant importance in recent decades as a means to reduce dependence on fossil fuels and promote sustainable development [56]. Hydrogen is widely regarded as a promising clean energy source due to its high energy density [13], environmental friendliness [57], and the fact that its combustion only produces water vapor, making it a zero-emission fuel [58]. Hydrogen can be produced through various methods, including water electrolysis [59], steam reforming of methane [60,61], and the cracking of petroleum gas or methanol [2]. However, the production of hydrogen from fossil fuels still generates greenhouse gas emissions. Therefore, it is crucial to develop and implement sustainable methods for hydrogen production. Using renewable energy sources such as wind, solar, and tidal power to supply electricity for water electrolysis is considered a promising approach to produce “green hydrogen” [62]. However, the efficiency of hydrogen production through water electrolysis is primarily hindered by the slow kinetics of the four-electron oxygen evolution reaction at the anode. Additionally, there is a risk of explosion due to the mixing of hydrogen and oxygen [3,63,64]. Fortunately, ammonia is commonly found in wastewater treatment plants, unused agricultural fertilizers, and animal metabolic products. Although its improper handling can still lead to environmental harm [65], the theoretical oxidation potential of ammonia (0.06 V vs. RHE) [49] is lower than that of the OER (1.23 V vs. RHE) [66]. Therefore, by replacing the OER with AOR and fully converting ammonia to N2 while coupling it with HER, pollution can be reduced, and hydrogen production efficiency can be significantly improved (saving 95.1% of energy consumption, calculated as (1.23–0.06)/1.23 = 95.1%). AOR is a complex six-electron process with two known reaction mechanisms: the stepwise dehydrogenation O-S mechanism and the partial dehydrogenation G-M mechanism [67]. These complexities pose significant challenges for the practical application of AOR. Therefore, it is essential to design catalysts that are suitable for ammonia adsorption and intermediate detachment to enhance the catalytic activity, selectivity, and stability. It is generally considered that Pt is the most active electrocatalyst for AOR [38,68]. However, its high cost and susceptibility to poisoning by intermediates hinder its industrial applications [69,70]. Hence, reducing or eliminating the use of Pt presents an effective solution to overcome this bottleneck. Efforts have been made to develop new strategies that fall into two main categories. One category involves increasing the number of active sites, while the other focuses on strengthening the intrinsic activity of each active unit. Yin et al. [71] employed a solvothermal method (Fig. 11(a) ) to prepare ultra-small PtPb alloy catalysts with an average size of 2.6 nm (Figs. 11(b) and (c)). By introducing Pb to inhibit the adsorption of OHad on Pt sites, they successfully enhanced the competitive adsorption of ammonia on Pt sites, reducing the adsorption of intermediate NO x,ad/Nad, and releasing the reaction active sites in a timely manner. This achievement resulted in efficient ammonia oxidation coupled with hydrogen production, reaching a maximum AOR current density of 191.2 mA mg−1 Pt, while the OER current density was almost zero (Fig. 11(d)). After 1000 cycles of CV testing, the current density of PtPb/C only decreased by 40% (Fig. 11(e)). Additionally, compared to Pt/C (where the potential began to rise only after 50 seconds), this catalyst exhibited a slower increase in potential during AOR, reaching a sudden sharp increase after approximately 550 seconds due to poisoning effects. The authors attributed the excellent stability to p-d hybridization interactions that inhibit catalyst aggregation and Pb leaching. The slow increase in potential was attributed to the strong adsorption of NO x,ad/Nad on Pt sites, hindering the progress of AOR. As the OER occurred, it caused a sudden jump in potential (Fig. 11(f)). The large potential during the OER process led to the generation of nitrogen oxides and the oxidation of the electrocatalyst itself, ultimately resulting in catalyst deactivation. However, the methods mentioned above mainly rely on precious-metal-based catalysts. To further reduce costs, we should prioritize the development of non-precious-metal catalysts. Transition metals, owing to their unique properties, can provide abundant active sites for the adsorption and activation of ammonia and oxygen molecules, which are the key intermediates in AOR [72,73]. Furthermore, transition metals can undergo reversible redox reactions, participating in the multi-step reaction mechanism of AOR [74]. Additionally, we can modify the electronic structure and surface morphology of transition metals through various synthesis and post-treatment methods [33,75–77] to enhance their catalytic performance in AOR. Particularly, the choice of applied potential can influence the selectivity of AOR. Zhang et al. [78] synthesized the NiCu3-S-T catalyst on carbon paper, primarily producing N2 at low potentials (< 1.50 V vs. RHE), while nitrate and nitrite were predominant at higher potentials (> 1.60 V vs. RHE). Similarly, Nakayama et al. [79] reported that the NiCu bimetallic catalyst mainly converts ammonia to N2 at low potentials (< 0.6 V vs. Hg/HgO), whereas the oxynitrides were the primary products at high potentials (> 0.7 V vs. Hg/HgO). 3.3 AOR for sewage purification Improper treatment or discharge of ammonia-containing sewage has a detrimental impact on the aquatic environment, potentially leading to eutrophication. These ammonia sources typically originate from the following three main fields: (1) Industrial activities, such as fertilizer production, synthetic fiber manufacturing, and metal processing, which may result in the release of ammonia and an increase in its levels in wastewater. (2) Ammonia fertilizers and pesticides used in the agricultural fields, that can lead to effluents containing ammonia, and (3) The aquaculture industry which is another significant source of ammonia, producing animal excrement, particularly urine, rich in ammonia. Ideally, ammonia should be completely oxidized and converted into harmless nitrogen; however, due to limitations in reaction conversion efficiency and selectivity, incomplete oxidation of ammonia can result in the production of harmful nitrogen pollutants, including NOx compounds such as NO2 − and NO3 −). WHO has established a maximum allowable nitrate content of 10 mg L−1 in potable water [80]. To meet this standard, Nakayama's group [79] employed electrodeposition to introduce tetrabutylammonium cations (TBA+) into layered MnO2 and utilized ion exchange to replace the bulky TBA+ with denser transition metal ions (Ni2+ and Cu2+). This process resulted in a composite material known as NiCu/MnO2, where Ni2+ and Cu2+ ions were co-inserted into the layered MnO2 structure. Compared to MnO2 doped solely with Ni or Cu (Figs. 12(a) and (b) ), a rapid increase in current was observed at +0.53 V vs. Hg/HgO in the presence of NH3. This observation suggests a synergistic effect between Ni and Cu ions coexisting in the interlayer space of MnO2, which enhances the AOR activity of the catalyst. Notably, the oxidation-reduction wave of Ni2+/Ni3+ in NiCu/MnO2 became significantly sharper (Fig. 12(c)), indicating that the embedded Cu ions could expedite the oxidation of coexisting Ni2+. In other words, Cu ions could induce the electron transfer from NH3 to Ni3+, resulting in enhanced AOR performance. They also observed that during the long-term stability test, the current density of the NiCu/MnO2 catalyst gradually decreased due to the prolonged electrolysis time, which consumed a substantial amount of ammonia in the electrolyte. However, after 24 h of electrolysis operation, the current density was almost fully recovered to its initial value upon electrolyte replenishment (Fig. 12(d)). This confirms the durability of the electrode and the fact that NiCu/MnO2 did not deactivate during long-term testing. Gas chromatography was employed to analyze the products resulting from AOR, and the Faradaic efficiency (FE) of N2 was as high as 97.4%, while the FE of NO x was as low as 1.6% (Fig. 12(e)). Xue et al. [81] made adjustments to the electron distribution surrounding the oxygen atoms through co-doping with Cu and Fe. This modification effectively lowered the AOR reaction barrier of the Ni-Cu-Fe-OOH catalyst from 4.91 to 1.08 eV (Fig. 12(f)), resulting in a significant reduction in energy consumption. The Ni-Cu-Fe-OOH catalyst underwent pre-activation to produce a-NiCuFe, and it was observed that the Fe-doped catalyst exhibited superior AOR activity compared to a-NiCu, achieving approximately 60 mA cm−2 at 0.7 V (Fig. 12(g)). The AOR efficiency was assessed using the indigo carmine method before and after the AOR test, revealing the remarkable ammonia removal efficiency of the catalyst. As the reaction time increased, the ammonia concentration in the solution progressively decreased, as illustrated in Fig. 12(h). Furthermore, at a potential of 0.55 V, the ammonia removal efficiency reached 95.1%, as shown in Fig. 12(i). However, it is worth noting that the low FE observed at 0.6 V suggests that the high current is predominantly driven by the OER. Therefore, to achieve a higher FE in ammonia electrolysis, operating at a lower potential operation (< 0.4 V vs. SCE) proves to be an effective approach. This work opens up possibilities for the electrochemical removal of ammonia-nitrogen pollutants. Tawalbeh et al. [27] reported that NiO-TiO2 nanocatalysts exhibit efficient sewage treatment capabilities, with a 96.4% removal efficiency for ammonia (Fig. 13(a) ). This efficient process results in predominantly non-polluting nitrogen as the primary product of ammonia oxidation. Interestingly, NiO-TiO2 catalysts transformed NiOOH after treatment (Fig. 13(b)). Zhou et al. [82] discovered that while a high initial ammonia concentration did not favor the formation of N2 (Fig. 13(c)), an extended reaction time increased the yield of NO3 −. They also confirmed that pH variations had a negligible effect on product concentration (Fig. 13(d)). Shih et al. [26] declared that PtCu/G catalysts achieved a removal efficiency (R) of 97.4% at 1.5 mA cm−2, but NO3 − was the primary product (Figs. 13(e) and (f)). In parallel, this research investigated the influence of the initial ammonia concentration (C 0) on the removal efficiency, revealing that the highest selectivity to N2 was observed at C 0 = 50 mg mL−1. These findings underscore that ammonia concentration is one of the factors influencing product selectivity. 3.3.1 Oxidation of ammonia to nitrate Most studies have primarily focused on reporting the complete oxidation of ammonia to an environmentally friendly product, N2. However, the byproduct, nitrate (NO3 −), also warrants attention. The process of ammonia oxidation to nitrate plays a critical role in maintaining a balanced nitrogen cycle in various ecosystems [83]. Ammonia is a common waste product from sources such as animal waste and fertilizers. If ammonia accumulates without being converted to nitrate, it can lead to nutrient imbalances, water pollution, and eutrophication in aquatic systems [84]. On the other hand, nitrate is a form of nitrogen that can be taken up by plants as a nutrient. Generally, ammonia is first oxidized to nitrite, which is further oxidized to nitrate. The theoretical potential for the oxidation of ammonia to nitrate (NH4 + (aq) + 3H2O → NO3 − (aq) + 10H + (aq) + 8e−) is –0.88 V, involving a complex process of 10 proton and 8 electron transfers [85]. Chen's research group [86], employing a theoretical computational approach, dissected the mechanistic pathway of NH3 conversion to NO3 −. Figs. 14(a) and (b) reveal that in the O-S mechanism, the limiting potential for NO3 − formation is 1.13 V, which is lower than that of the G-M mechanism (1.30 V). By optimizing geometric models (Fig. 14(c)), they uncovered that the lowest energy adsorption configuration prior to nitrate generation involves the amalgamation of a nitrogen atom with the catalyst. Once the nitrate product is generated, the adsorption site transitions to an oxygen atom. Considering this phenomenon, in the design of catalysts for AOR, it is essential to consider both the M–N binding strength (M representing a transition metal) and the M–O binding strength, as a strong M–O bond favors the production of nitrate products. 4 Designing catalysts The catalytic activity, product selectivity, stability, cost, and catalytic reaction mechanism constitute five crucial factors that must be taken into consideration when designing catalysts suitable for industrial-scale AOR. Recent reports have indicated that Pt, Pd, and Rh (platinum group metals) are most extensively studied for AOR. Pt, at low temperatures, exhibits the highest reaction rate and N2 selectivity [87]. Conversely, at elevated temperatures, Pd demonstrates the maximum rate, while Pt exhibits the highest selectivity toward NO [88]. However, the high cost and resource scarcity of Pt raise sustainability concerns, particularly for long-term and large-scale applications. On the other hand, transition metals Ni and Cu are abundant in the Earth's crust and their compounds are easily synthesized; therefore, their catalytic performance can be optimized by adjusting catalyst structures [85,89]. Despite these advantages, transition metals suffer from low selectivity, yielding products other than N2, and are prone to corrosion, resulting in deactivation during prolonged reactions. Co-based catalysts also exhibit AOR activity under specific conditions but may encounter stability issues at elevated temperatures, primarily within the domain of DAFCs [65]. Table 1 summarizes recent research progress achieved with different catalyst types in AOR. It is worth noting that emerging single-atom catalysts (SACs), where metal atoms are isolated on solid supports, have garnered extensive research attention in fields like CO2 reduction and nitrate reduction for ammonia synthesis due to their strong metal-support interactions, high metal utilization, and catalytic activity [90–92]. Although SACs have not been studied in the field of AOR, we speculate that SACs with high atom utilization may present new opportunities for highly active AOR catalysts, which we intend to explore in future research. In conclusion, aside from the challenges mentioned earlier, factors such as the mechanism, pathway, and utilization of active sites in the ammonia oxidation reaction significantly influence AOR activity. Consequently, when designing catalysts, it is essential to carefully balance various factors to optimize catalytic performance. 5 Challenges and perspectives The investigation of AOR holds significant importance in the fields of DAFC, AOR-HER, and sewage purification. However, it also encounters several formidable challenges: (1) Complex mechanisms: Understanding the intricate mechanisms and intermediates involved in the AOR remains a significant challenge. Controversies persist regarding intermediate products and the internal mechanism responsible for selective N2 formation. (2) Catalyst development: The development of efficient and cost-effective catalysts for AOR is of paramount importance. Precious metals like Pt exhibit high activity, but their scarcity and cost raise sustainability concerns. Non-precious metal catalysts require improvements in terms of selectivity and stability. (3) Utilization of active sites: Maximizing the utilization efficiency of active sites on catalysts is essential. However, the phenomenon of catalyst reconstruction complicates the identification of the true active sites. (4) Product selectivity: Achieving high selectivity for environmentally benign products such as N2 over other byproducts, like NOx, remains an unsolved challenge. (5) Corrosion and poisoning: The durability of catalysts is a pressing concern, especially in long-term applications. Corrosion and poisoning can lead to catalyst deactivation and reduced efficiency. To fully leverage the research potential of AOR in the fields of clean energy and environmental preservation, several strategic avenues warrant exploration (Fig. 15 ): (1) Enhancing AOR activity: This should be considered a top priority, and can be achieved through various strategies, such as reducing the usage of high-activity Pt metals, exploring alternative high-activity catalysts, or designing different types of catalysts (e.g., SACs, heterojunctions, nanosheets, and defect-engineered catalysts). (2). Identifying catalyst active sites: The identification of catalyst active centers in the catalyst requires a synergy of in-situ characterization techniques (e.g., in-situ XAFS, FTIR, SEM, TEM, etc.) and complementary DFT modeling. (3) Elevating utilization efficiency of active center atoms: It is crucial to maximize the utilization efficiency of individual active center atoms. SACs can help expose catalytic active sites and tailoring suitable SACs for AOR based on their reaction mechanism may yield unprecedented results. (4) Selecting catalysts with moderate adsorption capabilities: Choosing catalysts with moderate adsorption capabilities for intermediate species like Nads can enhance selectivity toward environmentally friendly products (e.g., N2). (5) Enhancing catalyst durability: Improving catalyst durability involves the judicious use of protective coatings to mitigate corrosion and catalyst poisoning. 6 Conclusions In conclusion, this work provides an overview of the development of AOR research in the context of clean energy and environmental protection. We have summarized various aspects of AOR research, including the intricate reaction mechanisms unveiled through theoretical modeling and in-situ characterization techniques, catalyst design, and strategies for enhancing reaction efficiency. The review underscores the multifaceted potential of AOR, encompassing its role in DAFCs, its integration with the HER, and its significance in the purification of ammonia-containing wastewater. As we find ourselves at the crossroads of increasing energy demand and heightened environmental responsibility, AOR serves as a crucial link between clean energy production and sustainable wastewater treatment. Addressing the challenges outlined in this review and harnessing the mentioned potentials will continue to propel AOR toward more efficient and impactful applications in the fields of energy and the environment. Ultimately, this review serves as a guiding light for researchers and practitioners dedicated to contributing to a greener and more sustainable future through innovative AOR research and application. Jianying Huang received PhD degree in 2007 from College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Xiamen University. During 2007–2011, she is an assistant professor at Fujian Institute of Research on the Structure of Matter. Later, she acted as visiting scholar at Muenster University. From 2013 to 2018, she was an associate professor at School of Textile and Clothing Engineering in Soochow University. Currently, she is a full professor at College of Chemical Engineering at Fuzhou University, and selected as the 2019–2022 Highly Cited Researchers. Her research interests focus on bio-inspired surfaces with special wettability, advanced materials for energy and environmental applications. Yuekun Lai is a Fujian province “Minjiang Scholar” Chair Professor at the College of Chemical Engineering at Fuzhou University, and served as Editor of Chemical Engineering Journal. He received his PhD degree from the Department of Chemistry, Xiamen University. He is selected as the 2018–2022 Highly Cited Researchers (Clarivate Analytics) and the recipient of the 2016 Journal of Materials Chemistry A (JMCA, RSC) Emerging Investigators and 2019 Advanced Materials Interfaces (AMI, Wiley) Hall of Fame award. His current research topics are bioinspired intelligent materials with special wettability, multifunctional fabrics, conductive hydrogels and functional nanostructures for energy and environmental applications.

coredata.dc:description: In recent decades, the advancement of clean energy technologies and sewage purification has emerged as a focal point of research. This review focuses on the ammonia oxidation reaction (AOR) and summarizes its multifaceted applications, including its use in direct ammonia fuel cells (DAFCs), its coupling with the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), and its significance in ammonia-containing sewage purification. We discuss how the combination of in-situ characterization techniques and theoretical models has emerged as a powerful tool for exploring the AOR mechanism. The interplay of operational parameters such as temperature and pH, along with catalyst design, is emphasized in the context of DAFCs, highlighting the need for precise optimization to enhance efficiency. The importance of selectivity in the nitrogen gas product in ammonia-containing wastewater is also discussed. Furthermore, the review addresses the challenges and opportunities in AOR research, including strategies to enhance catalytic activity, identify active centers, maximize the utilization of catalyst atoms, and improve selectivity while ensuring catalyst durability. Ultimately, this review serves as a comprehensive guide for researchers and practitioners interested in harnessing the potential of AOR to bridge the gap between clean energy generation and sustainable wastewater treatment, offering insights into a greener and more environmentally responsible future.
